div.head: The Anabapti≈øticall Sermon.
The Text, Wa≈øh and be cleane.
div.p: BEloved, I am fil ‚Ä¢ ed with much zealous joy to behold ≈øo great an A≈ø≈øembly gathered together in this Chamber to heare me di≈øcover unto you new Doctrine upon the receiving of a n ‚Ä¢ w Member or Brother into our a≈ø≈øembly; who before had only the bare rags of Adam, and bap ‚Ä¢ ized by the ceremony of Antichri≈øt, who≈øe idolatrous cu≈øtomes which have bin u≈øed, hath drawn Gods heavy judgments upon us, for want of knowledge, being blinded with naturall corruptions: but I will cea≈øe my di≈øc ‚Ä¢ our≈øe at this time concerning that point, and will handle it in it's proper places, & come to the text. The words which I will pre≈øent unto your ob≈øervation ≈øhall be few in number, but weighty in ≈øub≈øtance, namely the≈øe, Wa≈øh and be cleane.

The fir≈øt of my Text, that is water, for the word wa≈øh doth naturally imply water, ≈øince we cannot wa≈øh without water, but we may have water and yet be ≈øo ≈ølovenly that we ≈øeldome wa≈øh at all. But this word wa≈øh in my text doth ≈øignifie our rebaptizing of our children, wherin the action is to wa≈øh, that is not to ≈øprinkle them with a little idolatrous water out of a Font or Ba≈øon; but to poure water on their heads, nay to dip them in water over head and eares, for ≈øuch dipping will fetch the ≈øaltne≈ø≈øe of ≈øinne out of their natures; and then follows the con≈øequent of this action, Wa≈øh and be clean? But fir≈øt I will de≈øcribe unto you the ≈øeverall ≈øorts of wa≈øhers, then ≈øpeake particularly of wa≈øhing, and after wa≈øhing I may very well conclude with, and be cleane.
There are as many ≈øorts of wa≈øhers as there are contaminated people; carele≈ø≈øe people, and fooli≈øh people.

Contaminated people are ‚Ä¢ ll the wicked and reprobate, who≈øe e≈øtates & lands are ours by propriety and right, being Gods children, and that it properly belongs to us; who becau≈øe they are not ≈øo pure as we are, ≈øo holy as we be; they wa≈øh them≈øelves to no purpo≈øe, and are like the ≈øigne of the Lab ‚Ä¢ ur in vaine, for it is uupo≈ø≈øi ‚Ä¢ le to wa≈øh them white or cleane; But wee that are brethren of the elect; we may wa≈øh our ≈øelves in a R ‚Ä¢ ver from the ≈øpots of our Carnality in every River, as Bow River, Hackny River, and other Rivers are to us a cleare Jordan, wherein we may baptize one another as we meane to do this day our late lo≈øt brother; Now you carele≈ø≈øe ≈øort of wa≈øhers, are ≈øuch as care not for this wa≈øhing, they thinke it enough to be ‚Ä¢ e wa≈øhed or rather watered with a little ≈øuperfluous water at their Chri≈ønings
as they call it, and by the Prie≈øt in the pre≈øence of three Gos≈øips to be Tom-nam'd, Iohn-nam'd, Dick-nam'd, or rather Nick-nam'd, for we hold it utterly unlawfull to baptize any untill they come to full years of under≈øtanding, that they may an≈øwer for them≈øelves, and conform them≈øelves to live according to that name and bapti≈øme which they have receiued; for litle John as long as he is in his infancy is not worthy to be named any thing but Iack, and ≈øo Richard may be called Dick, as a Blacke-bird that is kept in a Cage, and ≈øo all children that are chri≈øtned before they come to ripe yeares of under≈øtanding may be all called Nick, for their names are no names, but very Nick-names and By-names, till the baptized can an≈øwer the Baptizer, and ≈øpeake his owne name, as the ≈øpirit doth approve of his name, for how many in their younger dayes were baptized, and now growne men, and a≈øhamed of their Antichri≈øtian nam s, and run after their names like new begotten and regenerated Chri≈øtians. Wee may reade of whole hou≈øholds that were baptized, and indeed it was a great pollicy in tho≈øe times not to baptized by any name untill they come to full yeares.

And therefore though in former times Chri≈øtnings and Gos≈øipings did co≈øt a great deale of money to make a William or a Robert, which afterward proved a wicked Will, and a plundering Robert, like Prince Robers, let us encrea≈øe and multiply as fa≈øt as we c ‚Ä¢ n, but chri≈øten or baptize none of our children untill they are ready to be married them≈øelves, then let us call our daughters Hanua, Dorca; Mary, Lydia, Ruth, and Pri≈øcilla, and our ≈øonnes Nathaniel, Moy≈øes, Benoms, Annanias, Mana≈ø≈øes, Obadiah, and other ≈øuch like Scripture names: let us be wi≈øer then our fore-fathers, and walke out unto Rivers round about London, all which ≈øhall become ≈øpirituall Jordans unto the faithfull: I my ≈øelfe will lead you the way and ≈øhew you the manner of it, your need not feare drowning, for if you ≈øhould tread ami≈ø≈øe, and fall into a Whitlepit, (for there are many whitle-pits in Hackney and Bow Rivers, yet I can recover you againe; and I will bring you out, the Righteous you know many times, but ≈øuppo≈øe you ≈øhould fall over head and cares, yet you ≈øhould come out againe a good Chri≈øtian, in the regenerating water of either of the≈øe Rivers.

Now for the la≈øt part of my divi≈øion, which was concerning fooli≈øh people and w ‚Ä¢ ≈øhers, I account that all women are fooli≈øh wa≈øhers, two peny-worth of Soape is a great charge to them, and doth much trouble their con≈øciencs becau≈øe they wa≈øh nothing but linnen cloaths and foule raggs, but let us not ≈øtick for any charge that may conduce to the clen≈øing of our ≈øoules, but as we are ≈øanctified creatures, ≈øo let us be pure and holy in our conver≈øation, and wa≈øh our hands cleane of all ≈øin. There are other fooli≈øh wa≈øhers, or ≈ølutti≈øh wa≈øhers, ≈øo that the be≈øt Linnen put into their hands ≈øhall ≈øcape a ≈øcouring or a wa≈øhing, and the old dirt ≈øhall be apparent in them; but we though remaine as ≈øinfull as ever, wee mu≈øt under the vayle of Religion have a few
failings, and yet conditioned for holine≈ø≈øe, and ≈øurely we have it, at lea≈øt in the opinion of the world, we mu≈øt be clo≈øe in our actions, and ≈øtudy onely the my≈øterious arts of ≈øeeing, for opinion in matters of Religion cannot erre; we are held to be religious men, and therefore ≈øuch we are indeed, but yet we mu≈øt not joyne hands, heads, or hearts with the wicked, for they are reprobate people ordained onely to de≈øtruction, and Tophet is prepared for ≈øuch, and ≈øuch are tho≈øe C ‚Ä¢ valliers who≈øe inhumane cruelties the like were never heard of; but we are a holy and religious people, and the ≈øevere≈øt eye of Ju≈øtice cannot di≈øcerne a wrinckle, much le≈ø≈øe a ≈øpot in our actions. So me loo≈øe people, ig ‚Ä¢ orant and wicked rep ‚Ä¢ obates ≈øcoffe at us as if we were not halfe ≈øo holy as we would be beleeved to be, they have with narrow eyes ob≈øerved our actions, and finding them counterfeit they call us Round-he ‚Ä¢ ds; we are round indeed and ≈øound. Tho≈øe ≈øacred garments religion, which ≈øhewed nothing but decency (I mean ‚Ä¢ Surplices) are not to be e≈øteemed ≈øo much as my Wives ‚Ä¢ pron, and woe bee unto the womens hand ‚Ä¢ (for „Äà‚óä„Äâ they would rot f ‚Ä¢ om her wr ‚Ä¢ ≈øts) that ≈øhould wa≈øh a ≈øuper≈øtiticus Surpli≈ø≈øe. The Drunkard may be placed in the li≈øt of fooli≈øh wa≈øhers, ≈øwallowing all the gaines of h ‚Ä¢ s Trade by wa≈øhing his throat with good liquor, ‚Ä¢ ut let our d ‚Ä¢ aughts though few be co≈øtly, and of the be≈øt liquor we can get; and as in other matters let us at our holy fea≈øt make conjunction among≈øt our ≈øelves, and in the unity of the ≈øpirit joyne our monie for the releefe of our poore brethren, and for ≈øome wine which is be≈øt for the ≈øea≈øon, ≈øo we may wa≈øh our throates at a far cheaper rate than the reprobates doe, and be≈øi ‚Ä¢ es ≈øuch wa≈øhing of our throates after a good dinner or great fea≈øt, will make us ≈øtrong in the ≈øpirit, for the wine will fill our braines with divers good motions, and quicken us in the daily exerci≈øes of Religion, ≈øo that when our ≈øtomacks are well warm'd therewith we ≈øhall find our ≈øelves exceedingly comforted to proceed in the waies of godline≈ø≈øe, but walk not out of your chambers lea≈øt the winde take you, and you ≈øtumble into errors as the wicked doe.

My Ma≈øters, ≈øome of you (I beleeve,) when you ≈øit downe at the Table come with unwa≈øhed hands, for Trade≈ø-men eate our meat often with dirty fingers and foule hands, our hands mu≈øt be cleane wa≈øht to ≈øhew the purity of our profe≈ø≈øion; let therefo ‚Ä¢ e the Cook when he comes into an holy a≈ø≈øembly wa≈øh or lick his fingers: I wa≈øht my hands this morning becau≈øe I would handle the Text the better, cleanene≈ø≈øe doth become the Go≈øpell, and cleane fingers turning over the Go≈øpell doe not pol ‚Ä¢ ute the cleanne≈ø≈øe or leaves of it. Be≈øides, when a fea≈øt is made what doe all the be≈øt ≈øort of gue≈øts? they are very carefull to wa≈øh their hands before their comming thither, and after the fea≈øt is done be it dinner or ≈øupper what doth cu≈øtome place next upon the Table? verily a faire Ba≈øon and Ewer, and what to doe?
why the rea≈øon is, to make all the gue≈øts wa≈øh their hands; and the words of my Text are, wa≈øh and be cleane. This word cleane is taken in divers ≈øences, for fir≈øt if a man owe me mony upon a Bill or Bond, and afterward ab≈øent him≈øelfe and run away, it may be very well ≈øaid he is gone cleane out of ≈øight, and cleane away. Some ≈øay our religion is cleane contrary to the prote≈øtant profe≈ø≈øion, but ≈øuch are cleane out of the way, but if we ≈øhould be per≈øecuted againe by B ‚Ä¢ ≈øhops as formerly we have bin, we would run cleane out of England unto Am≈øterdam; but we are all cleane people, full of the purity of the ≈øpirit, our ≈øins are but motes in Gods eyes, but our brothers ≈øinnes are beames that have ≈øo put out the ≈øight of his divine Ju≈øtice, that he cannot or will not ≈øee our ≈ømall iniquities. But ≈øome will ≈øay, how know we that we are cleane? the ≈øpirit doth inwardly te≈øtifie unto us our goodne≈ø≈øe, our Prayers are ≈øo full of divine charmes that they can at Gods hands command audience; we are better than others whom we de≈øpi≈øe, and will not mingle our ≈øelves with the reprobate, but keep cleane out of their company.
